none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from C. Graves, January 10, 1883
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from C. Graves, January 10, 1883
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 13 Louis L. McInnis Papers

en: A letter from J. C. D. Graves, a former student of Professor Louis L. McInnis, written from Austin, Texas on January 10, 1883. Graves expresses his appreciation for his time under McInnis's instruction and requests mathematical assistance with calculating the length of a degree on the 32nd parallel of latitude for surveying work he has undertaken with Maddox Bros. & Anderson, a general land agency. The letter documents both personal reminiscence and a practical scientific inquiry related to land surveying in western Texas.

body.value:
[Header]

[Image: Building facade with text]
MADDOX BRO'S.
AND
ANDERSON. 509.
LAND OFFICE.

JNO. W. MADDOX.      F. M. MADDOX.      C. E. ANDERSON.
                                                              Formerly of the General Land Office
MADDOX BROS. & ANDERSON
GENERAL LAND AGENTS
509 CONGRESS AVE.
GEO. D. BARNARD & CO. ST. LOUIS.

Austin Tex. Jan 10th 1883

Prof. McInnis
College Station, Tex.
Dear Friend;
I wrote
you a letter while you were North
last Summer but did not receive a reply.
Of course, Professor, I could not ex-
pect you to carry on a correspondence
with me. It would take too much of your
time from your duties, but I would
like to hear from you once in a while.
I spent my happiest days while I was
under your instruction and the remem
brance of them will always be a
pleasure. Life has but few charms
for me and my pleasantest moments
are when I get a few spare moments
to continue my studies in mathematics
and take my mind from the cares of
the world. This language may sound

I noted that the "I" in "I wrote" is a stylized, oversized letter, and that the word "remembrance" is split across lines. Also that the "mathematics" might be an ambiguous character. I’ve carefully examined the “McInnis” and “College Station, Tex” portions to ensure accurate transcription.

Then, I focused on formatting and structuring the transcription using HTML tags. I'm double-checking any tricky words, such as "remembrance", "mathematics", and "expect", making sure the transcription accurately reflects what's on the page. I'm ensuring "North" and "Summer" and "Professor" are capitalized according to the source.

In essence, I'm combining my transcription skills with a methodical approach to deliver a high-quality reproduction of the text, paying close attention to every detail of the original.

[Header]

[1883, Jan. 10]

JNO. W. MADDOX.
F. M. MADDOX.
C. E. ANDERSON.
Formerly of the General Land Office.
MADDOX BROS. & ANDERSON
GENERAL LAND AGENTS
509 CONGRESS AVE. Austin, Tex. 188_
GEO. D. BARNARD & CO. ST. LOUIS.

[Body]

Strange from a person as young as my self but it is the truth. Since the 25th of August I have been employed with Maddox Bros and An- derson. Have spent about one half the time in the field surveying. I spent Christmas week running a connect- ing line from Horsehead Crossing in Pecos Co. to the mouth of Toyah Cr. I have been all over that western country. I wish to calculate the length of a degree on the 32nd Parrallel of Latitude un- less I can get it already calculated. Could you please give me a little assist- ance or instruction? The work must be very accurate to within 20 vrs. If you will please grant this request you will confer a great favor on

[Signature]

Your Old Student
J. C. D. Graves

**A Deep Dive into a Texas Surveyor's Letter** Okay, here's the transcription. I'm taking on this handwritten letter, and I need to be precise. Let's break this down. First, the image. The header is a bit busy. There's a building illustration on the left labeled "MADDOX BRO'S. AND ANDERSON. 509 LAND OFFICE.". Then there's the main letterhead in the center and right. Top right, in pencil, the date: `[1883, Jan. 10]`. Then comes the formal letterhead with the names "JNO. W. MADDOX.", "F. M. MADDOX.", "C. E. ANDERSON. Formerly of the General Land Office." in boxes, and below, the main title "MADDOX BROS. & ANDERSON" in a banner. Under that: "GENERAL LAND AGENTS". Below, the address "509 CONGRESS AVE.", then "Austin, Tex.", and the printed date "188_" (blank at the end). There's also tiny text: "GEO. D. BARNARD & CO. ST. LOUIS." at the bottom. ``` Let's dive deeper. * I've got a young man, J. C. D. Graves, writing to someone in the surveying field, likely an instructor or mentor. He starts by saying it's unusual for someone as young as himself to say it, but the truth is he's working for Maddox Bros and Anderson since August 25th. He's been spending about half his time surveying. * He mentions a Christmas week trip, connecting a line from Horsehead Crossing in Pecos Co. to the "mouth of Toyah Cr." - That "Toyah Cr." has me thinking. Is it "Toyah River"? Or a similar name. No, the context suggests it's Toyah Creek ("Cr.") and that's the only geographic fit. * He's asking for help calculating the length of a degree on the 32nd Parallel of Latitude, because he needs accuracy within 20 varas.
